Expectation1: Teaching children moral values and discipline
Situation1: The child is running around in a supermarket, and the parent needs to correct the behavior
Expectation2: Listen actively and provide emotional support when needed.
Situation2: Your I04iend calls you in the middle of the night, crying, because they just received some devastating family news.
Story: It was already a long day when I found myself in the supermarket, my son darting between aisles, giggling as he narrowly missed bumping into other shoppers. I knew I had to step in, to teach him about respect and discipline, to show him that running wild in public wasn’t acceptable. I took a deep breath, ready to call him over, when my phone buzzed in my pocket. It was my best friend, calling in the middle of the night, her name lighting up the screen. I answered, and immediately heard her sobbing—she could barely get the words out, but I understood enough: something terrible had happened in her family, and she needed me to listen, to be there for her, to offer comfort and support. My son’s laughter echoed down the aisle, drawing annoyed glances. I felt torn, my heart pulled in two directions—one part desperate to be the parent my child needed in that moment, the other aching to be the friend my friend needed, right now. I stood there, phone pressed to my ear, my son’s voice and my friend’s tears swirling around me, not knowing which role to answer first.
